info.game_comments:
Brian Weikle game 3.
Brian sets a new single-day cash winnings record of $52,000 and a new regular play cash winnings record of $104,800.

jeopardy_round: WHAT COULD SHE BE DOING IN THERE?

(1, 1).clue: This ringed planet is the farthest one from earth that can be seen with the naked eye

(2, 1).clue: 20 years before "Murphy Brown", her play "The Freezer" was named one of "the Best Short Plays of 1968"

(4, 1).clue: Giving herself a wavy look with a home one of these--if it doesn't work, she may not come out for days

(5, 1).clue: After an all-night negotiation led to a settlement, Tom Glavine revealed, "There is no strike" in this sport

(6, 1).clue: Frank Zappa's daughter thinks "Good Times" comic Jimmie is "Dy-no-mite!" & becomes this, like Buzz Aldrin

(1, 2).clue: It's actually too small to influence other planets' orbits, the theory that led to its discovery

(2, 2).clue: Jason Miller wrote & starred in a 1997 play about this actor nicknamed "The Great Profile"

(3, 2).clue: A first sale of stock on the open market:IPO

(4, 2).clue: Soothing her tired eyes with slices of this veggie that's popular in British tea sandwiches

(5, 2).clue: After that pretzel incident, she said, "You will be glad to know the president is practicing safe snacks"

(6, 2).clue: Sen. Rodham Clinton conquers Sir Edmund who conquered Everest & becomes...

(1, 3).clue: With thick clouds reflecting lots of light, this planet was once known as Lucifer & Phosphorus

(2, 3).clue: (Hi. I'm Paula Cale of Providence.) I originated the role of Suzanne in the play "Picasso at the Lapin Agile", written by this "wild & crazy guy"

(4, 3).clue: Improving her pedicure with this object made using ground corundum

(5, 3).clue: A former senator from Tennessee, he quipped in 2002, "I am concerned about the economy. I was the first one laid off"

(6, 3).clue: If actress Lange of "Peyton Place" turned on the "Heartlight" of singer Neil, she'd have this jewel of a name

(1, 4).clue: Astrologers say that when this "Planet of Communication" goes retrograde, stuff on Earth falls apart

(2, 4).clue: Now best remembered as a playwright, in his day he was famous for playing the ghost of Hamlet's father

(3, 4).clue: Furnisher of financial data on Wall St.:S&P

(4, 4).clue: Using a pumice stone to do this to her skin, from the Latin for "to strip leaves"

(5, 4).clue: Prodded about possible insider trading, she remarked on national TV, "I want to focus on my salads"

(6, 4).clue: Ms. Khan, once the lead singer of Rufus, feels for Senator Trent & gets this sweet name

(1, 5).clue: This planet's day is almost exactly the same as ours--24 hours, 37 minutes

(2, 5).clue: This British actress seen here based the heroine of her play "The Mandrake Root" on her mother, Rachel Kempson

(3, 5).clue: A salary increase in response to inflation:COLA

(4, 5).clue: Using this Jergens brand's strips to clean out her pores -- I wouldn't go in right now

(5, 5).clue: Regarding Mick Jagger's knighthood, he scoffed, "It's a paltry honor... hold out for the Lordship, mate"

(6, 5).clue: Ms. Frontiere, owner of the Rams, marries Lucrezia's brother Cesare & gets this rhyming name

(1, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from on location.) I'm in this famous urban area that covers 843 acres and boasts a skating rink and a zoo

(2, 1).clue: In 1962 Anthony Quinn played a fierce Bedouin leader in this desert epic

(4, 1).clue: Born in Connecticut in 1800, attacked a U.S. arsenal in 1859, hanged for treason the same year

(5, 1).clue: The record for the largest one of these garden favorites was of the beefsteak variety & weighed 7 lbs., 12 ounces!

(6, 1).clue: The ruins of the ancient city of Babylon are located just south of this capital city

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from on location.) I'm in this city at the site where Fort Dearborn was established in 1803; it's changed a bit since then

(2, 2).clue: Anthony Quinn is best remembered for his role as this earthy title peasant in a film based on a Kazantzakis novel

(3, 2).clue: What's gnu? Just another name for this large African antelope

(4, 2).clue: The first woman executed by the U.S. government, Mary Surratt was hanged for her involvement in this crime

(5, 2).clue: The first plant to receive a patent was the "New Dawn" species of this garden flower in 1931

(6, 2).clue: The Salix babylonica seen here is commonly known by this "unhappy" name

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from on location.) I'm on the slopes in the Arapaho National Forest in this state

(2, 3).clue: In this 1943 film "Incident", Anthony Quinn & Dana Andrews are mistakenly lynched by a mob

(3, 3).clue: Term for a tornado or whirlwind that occurs over a lake or ocean

(4, 3).clue: Cuauhtemoc, the last ruler of this empire, was hanged by Hernando Cortes

(5, 3).clue: There are Siberian, Dutch, and bearded varieties of this garden favorite

(6, 3).clue: Historians refer to the dispersion of these people after their Babylonian exile as "the Diaspora"

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from on location.)  I'm at a 1902 estate built by railroad mogul Henry Flagler in this state

(2, 4).clue: Kirk Douglas was Vincent Van Gogh & Anthony Quinn played Paul Gauguin in this artsy 1956 big screener

(3, 4).clue: It's the breed of dog seen here in a photo by William Wegman

(4, 4).clue: Benedict Arnold's co-conspirator, this British major was hanged as a spy on Oct. 2, 1780

(5, 4).clue: The Pascal variety of this crisp garden vegetable has nearly stringless stalks

(6, 4).clue: Following the capture of King Nabonidus in 539 B.C., this empire completed its conquest of Babylon

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from on location.) I'm enjoying a cappuccino in this Roman piazza, known for its Baroque masterpieces

(2, 5).clue: In 1962 Quinn played this title criminal set free so that Christ could be crucified

(3, 5).clue: It's the German equivalent of a child prodigy

(4, 5).clue: More than 50 white people were slain during the slave rebellion led by this messianic leader hanged in 1831

(5, 5).clue: In 1924 the popular magazine originally known as Fruit, Garden, and Home became this

(6, 5).clue: Break the code to discover he was the sixth ruler of Babylon's Amorite dynasty

(0, 0).clue: All of the mountains in the U.S. over 14,500 feet are in this state
